Description.val:
The Common Defensive Weapon System (CDWS) consists of a GAU-21 .50 cal machine gun, common cradle, ammo box, feed/link chutes and either a right-hand or a left-hand Medium Window Pintle Connector and a Defensive Armament System for UH-1Y, and a ramp mounted weapon system for MV-22. The CDWS for UH-1Y and MV-22 is being procured to replace the current WWII era GAU-16/XM-218 .50 cal machine guns. The GAU-16/XM-218 machine guns can no longer be procured, and the gun depot is experiencing a 29% rejection rate. Based on current usage rates and depot maintenance rejection rates, the inventory of GAU-16/XM-218 guns will be below requirement in 7 years. There will also be a substantial increase in maintenance funding required to sustain the inventory of usable guns. The CDWS will give the Fleet enhanced reliability, safety and increased operational effectiveness.  CDWS enhances the warfighters overall capability by providing a safer, more reliable and accurate weapon system with a higher rate of fire.

Medium Caliber Guns System modifies hardware to enhance system reliability and safety to support continued Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) commitments. This requirement will prevent degradation of the gun system enabling the warfighter to accomplish their tasks safely and accurately.

Justification.val:
FY 2014 provides funding to procure MV-22 ramp mount systems. FY 2014 funding will procure 46 modified RMWS for the MV-22 aircraft resulting in a $3.6M increase in funding from FY 2013.

FY 2012 OCO funding procured three modified CDWS MV-22 ramp mounted systems.

Name.@footnote: Procurement of the gun system starts in FY14. First fielding and support requires non recurring investment for Operator/Armorer training, tooling, and onsite support for first install. This along with introducing the systems at USMC major Command elements will be completed using FY14 support dollars. Support cost for the follow on procurements does not require the same level of support. This is reflected in the reduction in FY15-18 support cost in the budget.
FY 2012 MV-22 funding procured 3 modified Ramp Mounted Weapons System (RMWS) for the MV-22 aircraft. FY 2014 through the FYDP will procure the RMWS for MV-22 aircraft.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The Common Defensive Weapon System (CDWS) consists of a GAU-21 .50 cal machine gun, common cradle, ammo box, feed/link chutes and either a right-hand or a left-hand Medium Window Pintle Connector and Defensive Armament System for UH-1Y, and a Ramp Mounted Weapon System (RMWS) for MV-22. The CDWS for the UH-1Yand MV-22 is being procured to replace the current WWII era GAU-16/XM-218 .50 cal machine gun. The GAU-16/XM-218 machine gun can no longer be procured, and the gun depot is experiencing a 29% rejection rate. Based on current usage rates and depot maintenance rejection rates, the inventory of GAU-16/XM-218 guns will be below requirement in 7 years. There will also be a substantial increase in maintenance funding required to sustain the inventory of usable guns. The CDWS will give the Fleet enhanced reliability, safety, and increased operational effectiveness. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The GAU-21 .50 Caliber Machine Gun is a Commercial Off-the-Shelf (COTS) item deployed on Marine Corps assault support aircraft (CH-53 and UH-1Y). In FY 12 the current RMWS is being modified to accommodate the CDWS for MV-22.  The Medium Pintle Head and aircraft integration kit base designs are also COTS though kit modifications for each Type/Model/Series aircraft are required.  CDWS is also being integrated on United States Navy (USN) platform MH-60R/S through their own budget lines, thus enhancing the common configurations between USN and United States Marine Corps.

DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  Provides laser aiming devices for crew served weapons being used in Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom.  There are currently five different types of lasers manufactured by three vendors. This funding will allow the standardization of all Deparmetn of Navy Crew Served Weapons lasers through attrition and replacement as assets are expended.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Laser Aiming Devices are Commercial Off The Shelf items already deployed on Marine Corps assault support aircraft (CH-53,and UH-1Y, MV-22, AH-1W/Z). Lasers will support this functionality to improve performance in a night environment while using night vision goggles.

DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: Increased usage of medium caliber gun systems in Operation Enduring Freedom has caused significant increases in component failure and reduced reliability and life cycle which was not previously budgeted.   This requirement will prevent degradation of the gun system enabling the warfighter to fight safely and accurately.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Medium Caliber Gun Systems are post Full Operational Capability (FOC). M89E1 Feeder is post FOC.
